articles.title: These iconic corals are nearly extinct due to heatwaves: can they be saved?
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03466-xFlorida’s primary reef-building corals have been declared ‘functionally extinct’ — prompting a shift in conservation strategies.
articles.content:
Elkhorn coral off the coast of Key Largo, Florida. Credit: Sam Hodge/Alamy

Two years after a record-setting heatwave, scientists have confirmed that two iconic corals that have flourished across Florida’s 560-kilometre-long reef for more than 10,000 years are now ‘functionally extinct’ off the state’s southern coast.

Both the elkhorn coral (Acropora palmata) and staghorn coral (Acropora cervicornis) survive in tanks and scattered locations across Florida’s reefs, but a study published today in Science suggests that their long-standing role as the primary reef builders off the coast of Florida has come to an end: so few remain that they can no longer play a functional part in the ecosystem1.

“This ecosystem is forever transformed,” says study co-author Ross Cunning, a coral biologist at the John G. Shedd Aquarium in Chicago, Illinois. That does not mean scientists are giving up hope on either species, he says, but what scientists and conservationists do from now on “needs to fundamentally change”.

Boiling ocean

Over the past few decades, Florida’s corals have been hit repeatedly by bleaching events, which occur when rising water temperatures cause corals to expel the symbiotic algae that provide them with nutrients and colour. But the 2023 heatwave, which coincided with record temperatures that drove bleaching around the globe, hit Florida earlier, faster and harder than anything scientists had seen before.

Coral die-off marks Earth’s first climate ‘tipping point’, scientists say

Ocean temperatures registered above 31 °C for nearly 41 days — up to 4 degrees above normal in places. This created heat exposures on the reef that were two to four times higher than previous records. Although many corals survived the event, mortality among Acropora corals ranged from 98–100% across much of the reef, from Dry Tortugas National Park in the west through the Florida Keys to the east. In the area off the coast of Miami, and farther north, more than 60% of the corals survived.

The 2023 heatwave was the nail in the coffin not just for Acropora corals, but also for more than two decades of conservation work that has focused mainly on raising these corals in laboratories and then planting them back in the ocean, says Ken Nedimyer, technical director at Reef Renewal, a conservation organization in Tampa, Florida. Most of the corals that the organization has raised and planted over the past two decades are now dead. So, Nedimyer says his team’s efforts are now shifting towards other types of corals that have survived the bleaching events, such as brain and star corals, while also working to preserve the genetic diversity of Acropora corals and to breed those rare individuals that survived.

“We still have some great [Acropora] corals to work with,” Nedimyer says, and there is already evidence that such breeding efforts can help the corals to adapt and withstand future heatwaves. “We just haven’t done it at a big scale yet.”

This represents a hopeful and inspiring effort to adapt and restore vital reef ecosystems, with broad ecological significance.
articles.personality_title: Florida’s iconic corals declared functionally extinct, new efforts focus on heat-resistant species
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Florida’s coral reefs, which stretch for 560 kilometres, have been home to two important corals called elkhorn and staghorn for over 10,000 years. These corals help build reefs that support many sea creatures.

**What happened** – In 2023, a very strong heatwave raised ocean temperatures well above normal for over a month. This caused most elkhorn and staghorn corals to die—between 98% and 100% in many areas. Scientists now say these corals are ‘functionally extinct’ because so few remain that they cannot build reefs like before.

**Impact** – This is the first time such a major reef-building coral has been lost in this way due to climate change. It means Florida’s reef ecosystem is changed forever. Conservation groups had spent years growing these corals in labs and planting them back in the ocean, but most did not survive the heat. This shows old methods alone are not enough.

**What’s next step** – Conservation efforts are now shifting to protecting other coral types like brain and star corals that survived better. Scientists also want to breed the rare elkhorn and staghorn corals that did survive, hoping to help them adapt to warmer waters. These new strategies aim to save coral reefs by focusing on heat-resistant corals and preserving their genetic diversity.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After a devastating heatwave wiped out Florida’s key reef-building corals, scientists are changing their approach to protect and breed heat-tolerant corals to help reefs survive future warming.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les coraux emblématiques de Floride déclarés fonctionnellement éteints, les efforts se tournent vers les espèces résistantes à la chaleur
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les récifs coralliens de Floride, qui s’étendent sur 560 kilomètres, abritent depuis plus de 10 000 ans deux coraux importants appelés corail cervicornes et corail elkhorn. Ces coraux aident à construire des récifs qui soutiennent de nombreuses espèces marines.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2023, une vague de chaleur très intense a fait monter la température de l’océan bien au-dessus de la normale pendant plus d’un mois. Cela a entraîné la mort de la plupart des coraux elkhorn et cervicornes – entre 98 % et 100 % dans de nombreuses zones. Les scientifiques déclarent maintenant ces coraux « fonctionnellement éteints » car si peu restent qu’ils ne peuvent plus construire de récifs comme avant.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois qu’un corail constructeur de récifs aussi important disparaît à cause du changement climatique. Cela signifie que l’écosystème récifal de Floride est changé à jamais. Les groupes de conservation avaient passé des années à cultiver ces coraux en laboratoire puis à les replanter dans l’océan, mais la plupart n’ont pas survécu à la chaleur. Cela montre que les méthodes anciennes ne suffisent plus.

**Prochaine étape** – Les efforts de conservation se concentrent maintenant sur la protection d’autres types de coraux, comme les coraux cerveau et étoile, qui ont mieux survécu. Les scientifiques veulent aussi élever les rares coraux elkhorn et cervicornes survivants pour les aider à s’adapter aux eaux plus chaudes. Ces nouvelles stratégies visent à sauver les récifs en se concentrant sur les coraux résistants à la chaleur et en préservant leur diversité génétique.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Après une vague de chaleur dévastatrice qui a anéanti les coraux principaux de Floride, les scientifiques changent d’approche pour protéger et élever des coraux tolérants à la chaleur afin d’aider les récifs à survivre au réchauffement futur.
articles.personality_title_es: Corales icónicos de Florida declarados funcionalmente extintos; nuevos esfuerzos se centran en especies resistentes al calor
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los arrecifes de coral de Florida, que se extienden por 560 kilómetros, han albergado durante más de 10,000 años dos corales importantes llamados coral cuerno de alce y coral cuerno de ciervo. Estos corales ayudan a construir arrecifes que sostienen muchas especies marinas.

**Qué pasó** – En 2023, una ola de calor muy fuerte elevó la temperatura del océano mucho más de lo normal durante más de un mes. Esto causó la muerte de la mayoría de los corales cuerno de alce y cuerno de ciervo — entre un 98 % y 100 % en muchas áreas. Los científicos ahora dicen que estos corales están ‘funcionalmente extintos’ porque quedan tan pocos que ya no pueden construir arrecifes como antes.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que un coral constructor de arrecifes tan importante se pierde debido al cambio climático. Esto significa que el ecosistema del arrecife en Florida ha cambiado para siempre. Los grupos de conservación habían pasado años cultivando estos corales en laboratorios y plantándolos de nuevo en el océano, pero la mayoría no sobrevivió al calor. Esto muestra que los métodos antiguos no son suficientes.

**Próximo paso** – Los esfuerzos de conservación ahora se centran en proteger otros tipos de corales, como los corales cerebro y estrella, que sobrevivieron mejor. Los científicos también quieren criar los raros corales cuerno de alce y cuerno de ciervo que sobrevivieron, con la esperanza de ayudarles a adaptarse a aguas más calientes. Estas nuevas estrategias buscan salvar los arrecifes enfocándose en corales resistentes al calor y preservando su diversidad genética.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Tras una devastadora ola de calor que eliminó los corales clave de Florida, los científicos están cambiando su enfoque para proteger y criar corales tolerantes al calor y ayudar a los arrecifes a sobrevivir al calentamiento futuro.
